name: Auto-Create GitHub PRs & JIRA Updates from Git Commit Commands (Multi-Repo)

user.name: Intuz
user.bio:
Workflow automation can help automate your routine activities and help saves $$$, as well as hours of time. 

As a boutique tech consulting company, Intuz help  businesses with custom AI/ML, AI Workflow Automations, and software development. 


Automate your business workflow for: 
Sales
Marketing
Accounting
Finance
Operations
E-Commerce
Customer Support
Admin & Backoffice 
Logistics & Supply Chain

description:
# This n8n template from [Intuz](https://www.intuz.com/) provides a complete and automated solution for scaling your DevOps practices across multiple repositories.

Are you tired of the repetitive dance between git push, creating a pull request in GitHub, updating the corresponding task in JIRA, and then manually notifying your team in Slack, or Notion? 

This template puts your entire post-commit workflow on autopilot, creating a seamless and intelligent bridge between your code and your project management.

By embedding specific keywords and a JIRA issue ID into your git commit commands, this workflow automatically creates a Pull Request in the correct GitHub repository and updates the corresponding JIRA ticket. This creates a complete, centralized system that keeps all your projects synchronized, providing a massive efficiency boost for teams managing a diverse portfolio of codebases.

## Who This Template Is For?

This template is a must-have for any organization looking to streamline its software development lifecycle (SDLC). It‚Äôs perfect for:

- Development Teams: Eliminate tedious, manual tasks and enforce a consistent workflow, allowing developers to stay focused on coding.
- DevOps Engineers: A ready-to-deploy solution that integrates key developer tools without weeks of custom scripting.
- Engineering Managers & Team Leads: Gain real-time visibility into development progress and ensure processes are followed without constant check-ins.
- Project Managers: Get accurate, automatic updates in JIRA the moment development work is completed, improving project tracking and forecasting.


## Step-by-Step Setup Instructions

Follow these steps carefully to configure the workflow for your environment.

**1. Connect Your Tools (Credentials)**
- GitHub: Create credentials with repo scope to allow PR creation.
- JIRA: Create an API token and connect your JIRA Cloud or Server instance.
- Slack: Connect your Slack workspace using OAuth2.
- Notion: Connect your Notion integration token.

**2. Configure the GitHub Webhook (For Each Repository)**

This workflow is triggered by a GitHub webhook. You must add it to every repository you want to automate.
- First, Save and Activate the n8n workflow to ensure the webhook URL is live.
- In the n8n workflow, copy the Production URL from the Webhook node.
- Go to your GitHub repository and navigate to Settings > Webhooks > Add webhook.
- In the Payload URL field, paste the n8n webhook URL.
- Change the Content type to application/json.
- Under "Which events would you like to trigger this webhook?", select "Just the push event."
- Click "Add webhook." Repeat this for all relevant repositories.

**3. Configure the JIRA Nodes (Crucial Step)**

Your JIRA project has unique IDs for its statuses. You must update the workflow to match yours.

- Find the two JIRA nodes named "Update task status after PR" and "Update the task status without PR."
- In each node, go to the Status ID field.
- Click the dropdown and select the status that corresponds to "Done" or "Development Done" in your specific JIRA project workflow. The list is fetched directly from your connected JIRA instance.

**4. Configure Notification Nodes**

Tell the workflow where to send updates.

- For Slack: Open the two nodes named "Send message in slack..." and select your desired channel from the Channel ID dropdown.
- For Notion: Open the two nodes named "Append a block in notion..." and paste the URL of the target Notion page or database into the Block ID field.

**5. Final Activation**

Once all configurations are complete, ensure the workflow is Saved and the toggle switch is set to Active. You are now ready to automate!



## Customization Guidance

This template is a powerful foundation. Here‚Äôs how you can adapt it to your team's specific needs.

**1. Changing the PR Title or Body:**

- Go to the "Request to create PR" (HTTP Request) node.
- In the JSON Body field, you can edit the title and body expressions. For example, you could add the committer's name ({{$('Webhook').item.json.body.pusher.name }}) or a link back to the JIRA task.

**2. Adapting to a Fixed Branching Strategy:**

- If your team always creates pull requests against a single branch (e.g., develop), you can simplify the workflow.
- In the "Request to create PR" node, change the base value in the JSON body from {{...}} to your static branch name: "base": "develop".
- You can then remove the base branch logic from the "Commit Message Breakdown" (Code) node.

**3. Modifying Notification Messages:**
- The text sent to Slack and Notion is fully customizable.
- Open any of the Slack or Notion nodes and edit the text fields. You can include any data from previous nodes, such as the PR URL ({{ $('Request to create PR').item.json.body.html_url }}) or the repository name.

**4. Adjusting the Commit Regex for Different Conventions:**

- This is an advanced customization. If your team uses a different commit format (e.g., (DEV-123) instead of DEV-123), you can edit the regular expression in the "Commit Message Breakdown" (Code) node. Be sure to test your changes carefully. 

**5. Adding/Removing Notification Channels:**

- Don't use Notion? Simply delete the two Notion nodes.
- Want to send an email instead? Add a Gmail or SMTP node in parallel with a Slack node and configure it with the same data.


## Connect with us
- Website: https://www.intuz.com/services
- Email: getstarted@intuz.com
- LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/company/intuz
- Get Started: https://n8n.partnerlinks.io/intuz

## For Custom Worflow Automation
Click here- [Get Started](https://www.intuz.com/get-started)

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.

parameters.text: =PR has been created for the repository '{{ $('Webhook').item.json.body.repository.name }}' and task status of the task {{ $('Get task details for PR').item.json.key }} has been changed to development done

parameters.text: =Task status of the task {{ $('Get Task Details without PR.').item.json.key }} has been changed to development done

nodes.name: Append a block in notion with PR

blockValues.textContent: =PR has been created from the repository {{ $('Webhook').item.json.body.repository.name }} and task status for the task{{ $('Get task details for PR').item.json.fields.parent.key }}  has been updated to Development Done

nodes.name: Append a block in notion without PR

blockValues.textContent: =Task status for the task {{ $('Get Task Details without PR.').item.json.key }} has been updated to Development Done

parameters.content:
## üîß Quick Setup Required!

Welcome! To make this workflow yours, you just need to do two things:

1.  **Connect Your Accounts:** Click on the GitHub and Jira nodes and select your credentials. Also, add the slack and notion credentials to ensure smooth message delivery

2.  **Add Webhooks to the required repositories:** Add the production webhook link to the concerned repositories
 


That's it! You're ready to automate.

### Step 1: Webhook Activated! ü™ù

This is the entry point of the workflow.

It acts as a **listener for GitHub push events**, tapping into your repositories to catch every new commit.

Here‚Äôs what it does:

- üì¶ Listens for `push` requests on specific branches.
- üö¶ Triggers the workflow only when new commits hit the repo.
- üéØ Ensures everything starts from the moment you push code.

It‚Äôs the spark that kicks off the automation engine. üîß‚ö°

### Step 2: The Decoder Ring üß†

This is where the magic happens! Think of this node as a translator.

It carefully reads the commit message you wrote (e.g., "FF-1196...[auto-pr]...") and intelligently pulls out the three key pieces of information we need:

1.  **Who:** The Jira ticket number.

2.  **What:** The special commands (`[auto-pr]`, `[taskcompleted]`).

3.  **Where:** The target branch for the PR.

### Step 3: To PR, or Not to PR? ü§î

This is a checkpoint that gives you control.

It asks a simple question: "Did the developer include the `[auto-pr]` command?"

- If **YES**, we proceed down the "True" path to create the Pull Request automatically. No more manual form-filling in GitHub!

- If **NO**, we skip it. This lets you push multiple work-in-progress commits without flooding your team with PRs.

### Step 4: Task Intel Incoming! üïµÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

This node is your mission control for task details.

It takes the **Jira ticket number** extracted in Step 2 and dives into your project management system to fetch all the juicy details‚Äîlike the task title, status, assignee, and more.

In short: it‚Äôs the bridge between your code and your backlog. üß©

### Step 5: PR Radar Activated! üì°

This node is on patrol to prevent duplicates.

It scans the repository to check if a **Pull Request already exists** from the current branch. Why? Because creating multiple PRs for the same work = chaos. üß®

- If a PR already exists, we skip creating a new one.
- If no PR is found, we move ahead to create it.

Simple, smart, and keeps your GitHub tidy. üßº

### Step 6: PR Data Extractor üß†üìÑ

This node digs into GitHub to check if a **Pull Request already exists** for the current branch.

Here‚Äôs what it does:

- ‚úÖ **If a PR exists**: It extracts and formats key details like PR title, description, status, URL, and number‚Äîready to be used in the next steps.
- ‚ùå **If no PR is found**: It returns `false`, signaling that a new PR may need to be created.

This step ensures we always work with clean, structured data‚Äîand avoid duplication. üì¶üßπ

### Step 7: PR Data Merge Hub üîóüß©

This node acts as a smart **merge point** for Pull Request data.

It brings together inputs from:

- üß† **Extracted PR details** (if a PR already exists).
- ‚úÖ **PR existence check** (whether or not a PR is found).

What‚Äôs the result?

- A single, unified dataset that combines both logic and content.
- Downstream nodes can now operate on **consistent and complete PR info**, regardless of the path taken.

Think of it as your data convergence checkpoint‚Äîclean, connected, and ready to go. üîÑüß∑

### Step 8: Launch the PR! üöÄ

This is the final move‚Äîthe grand finale.

If everything checks out, this node **creates the Pull Request** automatically using the details we gathered earlier (task info, branch name, etc.).

No manual clicking. No copy-pasting. Just:

- ‚úÖ A clean PR title.
- üìù A brief and clean description

It‚Äôs automation magic at its finest. ‚ú®

### Step 7: Status Update Sent! üì¨

Time to close the loop with Jira.

This node takes care of updating the **task status to ‚ÄúDevelopment Done‚Äù** once the PR is successfully created.

Why does this matter?

- ‚úÖ Keeps your Jira board up to date automatically.
- üìä Gives your team instant visibility into progress.
- üîÑ Ensures a smooth handoff to the next stage (like QA or Code Review).

No need to switch tabs‚Äîyour workflow just updated itself. üîÅ

### Heads-Up Node: Something‚Äôs Missing! ‚ö†Ô∏è

This node acts as a checkpoint when things don‚Äôt go as planned.

It checks two key conditions:

1. ‚ùå The **Jira task** couldn‚Äôt be found based on the commit message.
2. üõë The PR **does not include** the `[taskcompleted]` keyword.

If either is true, we **skip the task status update** to avoid pushing incomplete or incorrect changes to Jira.

It‚Äôs a safety net to keep your workflow clean and error-free. üßØ

### Step 8: Spread the Word! üì£

Time to notify the crew.

These nodes send out alerts that a **Pull Request has been created** and the **Jira task status has been updated**‚Äîall in real-time.

Where does the message go?

- üí¨ **Slack** ‚Äì Keeps your team in the loop instantly.
- üóÇÔ∏è **Notion** ‚Äì Logs the activity for async tracking and documentation.

Clear, consistent, and automatic communication. Your workflow just became a team player. ü§ù

### Halt! Invalid Commit Detected üö´

This node is the gatekeeper for clean automation.

It checks if the commit message is **missing the required format or commands** (like `[auto-pr]`, `[taskcompleted]`, etc.).

If the message is invalid or empty:

- üõë The workflow is **stopped immediately**.
- üîí No PR is created.
- ‚ö†Ô∏è No task is updated.

This ensures only intentional, well-formed commits trigger automation‚Äîkeeping your pipeline smart and safe. üß†‚úÖ

### Step 4: Task Completion Check ‚úÖ‚ùì

This node plays detective for the `[taskcompleted]` command.

It scans the commit message to see if you‚Äôve marked the task as complete‚Äîby including the `[taskcompleted]` keyword.

Why is this important?

- ‚úÖ If present, we‚Äôll proceed to update the Jira task status in later steps.
- ‚ùå If missing, we assume the task isn‚Äôt done yet and **skip the status update**.

It‚Äôs a smart way to give **you control over when the task is marked complete**‚Äîall from the comfort of your commit message. üßò‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

### Step 5: Task Hunt Begins! üîç

This node verifies whether the **Jira task actually exists**.

Using the ticket number extracted earlier, it queries Jira to confirm that the task is valid and accessible.

Here‚Äôs what it does:

- ‚úÖ If the task exists, we move forward confidently.
- ‚ùå If not, we stop here to avoid pushing changes to a non-existent or incorrect task.

Think of it as a sanity check‚Äîbecause broken links to Jira help no one. üß†üõë

### Step 6: Silent Status Update ü§´‚úÖ

This node updates the **Jira task status to ‚ÄúDevelopment Done‚Äù**, but skips the PR creation process.

Why would this happen?

- The commit message includes `[taskcompleted]`, but **does not** include `[auto-pr]`.
- You want to mark the task as finished **without creating a Pull Request**‚Äîfor example, in cases of non-code or internal changes.

It‚Äôs a clean way to **signal task completion in Jira** while keeping your GitHub untouched. üéØ

### Step 7: Task Update Broadcast! üì¢

This node handles communication after the Jira task status has been updated.

It sends out friendly alerts to keep everyone in the loop:

- üí¨ **Slack** ‚Äì So your team knows the task has moved to ‚ÄúDevelopment Done‚Äù.
- üóÇÔ∏è **Notion** ‚Äì For async tracking, visibility, and documentation.

No more ‚ÄúDid you finish this?‚Äù messages‚Äîyour workflow answers for you. ‚úÖüßò‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

### ‚úçÔ∏è Commit Message Command Guide Your `git commit` message is the remote control for this automation. Use the format below to trigger specific actions. **Base Format:** `TICKET-ID Your descriptive message [command1,command2,base-branch]` --- | Commit Message Example | Commands Used | Automation Triggered | | :--- | :--- | :--- | | **`DEV-123 Fix login bug [auto-pr, taskcompleted, develop]`** | `[auto-pr]`
`[taskcompleted]`
`develop` | **üöÄ Full Automation:**
1. Creates a Pull Request to the `develop` branch.
2. Updates Jira task `DEV-123` to "Done".
3. Sends notifications about both actions. | | **`DEV-456 WIP on new UI [auto-pr, main]`** | `[auto-pr]`
`main` | **‚öôÔ∏è PR Creation Only:**
1. Creates a Pull Request to the `main` branch.
2. Jira task status is **not changed**. | | **`DEV-789 Final docs added [taskcompleted]`** | `[taskcompleted]` | **‚úÖ Jira Update Only:**
1. **No Pull Request** is created.
2. Updates Jira task `DEV-789` to "Done".
3. Sends notifications about the task update. | | **`DEV-111 Minor typo fix`** | *None* | **üö´ No Automation:**
The commit is pushed, but the workflow does nothing. This is for standard commits that don't need automation. | | **`DEV-222 This will fail [auto-pr]`** | `[auto-pr]` | **‚ö†Ô∏è Error - Workflow Stops:**
The workflow's validation will catch that `[auto-pr]` was used without a target branch and will stop, preventing an error. |

main.node: Check whether a PR already exists
Update the task status without PR
Send message in slack with PR
Append a block in notion with PR
Send message in slack without PR
Append a block in notion without PR
